Press the left or right key to traverse the slideshow
You can also use the spacebar to navigate the slideshow
StrideShow is a web+mobile presentation web application

Download the mobile app

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED but optional: The app is a significant part of a StrideShow presentation

The rest of this tutorial involves the mobile app
On the app's main page, click the "Proceed to Demo" button

In the demo activity,

1. Tap the StrideShow icon on the menu toolbar at the top of the phone screen to reveal the connection fragment

2. Enter the generated room number that you see under "Socket Status" (you won't be able to see it in fullscreen mode) into your
mobile device and press "Enter Room"

3. Wait for the "Mobile Status" on top (just beside Socket Status) to indicate that your mobile device has connected

Look back at your mobile device.

Close the connection fragment by tapping the StrideShow icon again.

Tap the "Instructions" presentation to control it through your phone.
You can now swipe left and right on the view pager to traverse the slideshow on this browser. Continue controlling this presentation on mobile
Switch to full screen by clicking the button on the bottom right of this slideshow container
On your mobile device, try the laser pointer by dragging the circular enclosed plus sign around

Try the speech recognizer

"Next Slide"

"Previous Slide"

More speech recognition keywords coming soon!
That's it for this tutorial. Exit the slideshow and check out the other presentations in this demo

steps.title: overview
first-slide
steps.html:
Introduction to Vault for Users

A product created by Hashicorp

steps.title: hashicorp
steps.html:
Hashicorp

  • Consul
  • Vagrant
  • Terraform

steps.title: vault-secrets
steps.html:
Securely stores and controls access to:

  • tokens
  • passwords
  • certificates
  • API keys

steps.title: features
steps.html:
Features

  • Access controls
  • Audit logs
  • Encrypted storage
  • Break glass features

steps.title: vault-interface
steps.html: Interface: Command line

steps.title: backends
steps.html:
Secrets Backends

  • Are "roots" of a filesystem
  • Different types of backends for different types of secrets
  • Types: generic, aws, cubbyhole, and more
$ vault mounts

steps.title: mounts-example
steps.html:
$ vault mounts
PATH           TYPE           DESCRIPTION

General/       generic        general secrets
awsBackend/    aws            dynamic aws secrets
Gene42dev/     generic        secrets for Gene42 devs
Gene42clients/ generic        secrets belonging to Gene42 clients
PhenotipsDev/  generic        secrets phenotips developers
sys/           system         system endpoint used for control, ...
Cubbybox/      cubbybox       per token secrets

steps.title: authentication
steps.html:
Authentication: Tokens

  • Vault has no sense of users, only tokens
  • Everybody authenticates with tokens
  • $ vault auth d08e2bd5-ffb0-440d-6486-b8f650ec8c0c
  • Once authenticated, tokens are stored locally
  • Tokens are automatically included in commands that require permissions
  • Tokens are assigned permissions

steps.title: auth-backend
steps.html:
Authentication Backends

  • Other methods to generate tokens
  • Entry points to get tokens
      • Examples
    • Github backend
    • Userpass backend
    • Token backend
    • TLS certificates
    • many others

steps.title: userpass
steps.html:
Userpass

  • Use a username and password to generate a token
$ vault auth -methods=userpass \
     username=foo \
     password=bar
  • Permissions are set to userpass entries instead of tokens

steps.title: ttl
steps.html:
TTL & Max TTL

  • Time to Live
  • Tokens and secrets have ttl's
  • Static secrets don't depend on ttl's. They exist until deleted
  • Dynamic secrets and tokens are deleted at the end of their ttl
  • TTL's can be renewed until Max TTL is reached
    Example for userpass
  • Userpass tokens with TTL = Max_TTL = 8 hours
  • Generated tokens last a "work day"

steps.title: user-permissions
steps.html:
User permissions

  • Create
  • Read
  • Update
  • List
  • sudo
  • deny (default)
path "secret/*" {
   capabilities = ["read", "list", "create", "update"]
}

path "secret/foo" {
   capabilities = ["read"]
}

path "secret/super-secret" {
   capabilities = ["deny"]
}

steps.title: writing
steps.html:
Writing a secret

$ vault write secret/devPassword \
     username=admin \
     password=Admin \
     ...
1 2 3 4
  1. Vault executable
  2. Command (Write)
  3. Path (Backend: secret)
  4. Key value pairs

steps.title: reading
steps.html:
Reading a secret

$ vault read secret/devPassword
1 2 3
  1. Vault executable
  2. Command (Read)
  3. Path
KEY            VALUE
username       admin
password       Admin
...

steps.title: listing
steps.html:
Listing a secret

$ vault list secret
1 2 3
  1. Vault executable
  2. Command (List)
  3. Path
KEYS
devPassword
...

steps.title: deleting
steps.html:
Deleting a secret

$ vault delete secret/devPassword
1 2 3
Success! Deleted 'secret/devPassword' if it existed.

Aside: GPG with Vault

  • Sending secrets outside of Vault
  • Keeping tokens and/or auth backend credentials (eg userpass)
